instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi, got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that doesnt turn on, no DFU mode, no signs of visible damage. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL>: 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> is 5.1v when using the upper left and lower right usb ports (looking at the board from the open bottom plate position)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
You can't expect DFU without <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

PLEASE, use schematic refference for components.
Locate it on boardview, then translate to schematic, if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Yes, i get  the 5.1 v in <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?
If good, post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.
Also check resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Diode mode:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0.0002

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 0.375

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages:

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>: 5.1v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>: 1.3v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDA</SIGNAL>: 5v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>: 5v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>: 0v


Resistance between <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23  is 60kohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"Resistance between <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23  is 60kohms"
Pay more atention when you read; is not first time when I asked such checkings.
Do you really get 60k between <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> pins???

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0.0002"
No need to check <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages then.
Switch to ohm scale and see if any big coils shows the same value.
Start with CPU coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
L7330 is 26 ohms to ground
L7420: 6 ohms
L7410: 10 omhs
L8102 : 75 omhs
L7701: 175 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Check all coils, including SSD ones.
If none gives the same value as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, then is safe to use voltage injection method.
First remove F7000 and see which side the short remains.
